security: Acknowledging the CIA's involvement, even though previously reported, was considered harmful to national security. As stated by Scowcroft, disclosure might prompt retaliation endangering U.S. personnel and interests overseas. The article details 'unprecedented amount of secret court proceedings' to maintain secrecy.
summary: The Washington Post reports that the CIA publicly acknowledged its involvement in the Glomar Explorer's attempts to raise a sunken Russian submarine after previously claiming such acknowledgment would harm national security.
summary_one_paragraph: In a Washington Post article by Timothy S. Robinson, the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) admitted its involvement in the Glomar Explorer project, aimed at raising a sunken Russian submarine from the Pacific Ocean floor. This admission, filed in a U.S. Court of Appeals document by the Justice Department, reversed the government's earlier stance that even acknowledging CIA involvement could harm national security. The case, brought by the Military Audit Project, involved secret court proceedings, including a secret opinion from Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, reflecting concerns that disclosing details of the project could provoke retaliation against U.S. interests, as warned by Brent Scowcroft.
title: CIA Admits Working to Raise Sub
sender: Timothy S. Robinson (Washington Post Staff Writer)
